column1: Data Analysis
Modelling
..Research Overview
..Aircraft Emissions
..The RFM
GPFD
To develop a fast, portable computer model which can simulate aerosol microphysical process.

Methodology

The aerosol microphysical model employed in the
heteromolecular nucleation, condensational growth, coagulation and the
removal by sedimentation of binary sulphuric acid-water particles to
predict the composition and size distribution of stratospheric
aerosols. This model has been successfully applied to estimate the
changes in background stratospheric aerosol surface area due to
aircraft sulphur emission. The principal advantage with this model is
that it is non-iterative (Jacobson, 1999), i.e. computing time is
minimised by finding semi-implicit solutions to the aerosol processes.
Condensation and coagulation are solved using the operator-split
method. Hence the effect of coagulation is determined in a
single iteration and the solution is volume conserving for any
time-step. Similarly, starting from the fundamental growth equation,
the solution for condensation growth is derived which does not require
iteration, conserves mass exactly, and is unconditionally stable. In
FAMMUS homogeneous nucleation and condensation is coupled so that
there is realistic competition between the two processes for the
With geometrically related size bin (44 bins for sulphuric acid-water
model takes about half an hour to complete a 7 year simulation of
stratospheric background aerosol layer on a 2 GHz Pentium 4 work

Current Development

At present, the model treats two component
aerosol system commonly found in stratosphere. However, it can be
easily extended to multiple (> two) component system where particles
can be both externally and internally mixed as shown  by
Jacobson (2002). Current work on FAMMUS is to extend it to cover
sulphuric acid - nitric acid - water solutions.

Future Development

The principal aim is to expand FAMMUS to
include tropospheric aerosol types and related processes so that it can
be run as a trajectory model or incorporated into larger 3D atmospheric

externally-mixed binary, ternary etc. combinations of distributions
and any number of components in each distribution (maintaining volume
conservation). Additional aerosol types we would like to include are

For modelling of aerosols near the

The action of aerosols as both CN and IN has the
ability to alter cloud properties.  In addition knowledge of the inclusion of aerosols into raindrops is needed to estimate wet deposition rates.
For each of the aerosol types we would like to have an aerosol
radiative model. This requires knowledge of the aerosol size
distribution, shape and refractive indices.  Then using Mie theory for
spherical particles or the discrete dipole approximation for
non-spherical particles we can calculate the optical properties
